characters: HOW YOU DO ANYTHING IS HOW YOU DO
EXT. BROADWAY, UPPER WEST SIDE. NIGHT
DUH COMMUNAL BATHROOM DO YOU WANT
INT. EMPTY RESTAURANT SPACE, BROOKLYN. DAY
INT. BACKSTAGE AT A MUSIC CLUB. NIGHT
EXT. UPPER MANHATTAN, BY THE HUSDON RIVER. NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: INT. DORM ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: A dark room. We hear movement from outside. A key in the lock. The door opens, light from the hallway silhouettes Tracy as she hauls in a bag on wheels. She feels for a li on the wall and hits the switch. The lights come on.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I was sleeping! Turn that off! Tracy shuts the light.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Sorry. (pause) I’m your roommate.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My name is Laura...

dialogues.speaker: INT. DORM COMMON ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: A group of ten freshman sit around in a circle. One girl, Laura, holds a flashlight and says:

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: .--and I’m going on safari and I’m bringing with me a ROLLING PIN for Ruth, a CAR for Carrie... (everyone laughs) A JAR for Juman and a... a... shit. She stares at Tracy, unable to get her name. Tracy pipes

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: A TRACKING DEVICE for Tracy...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: ..-Right a TRACKING DEVICE for Tracy and a...LIGHTER for me, Laura. She passes the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy sits in her new dorm-room with her roommate, a girl with mousy hair and a hoodie. She watches Tracy unpack, f her bed.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Aren’t you coming to convocation?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You're going to that shit?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah... isn’t everyone?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t think anyone is going. Except rapists.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What? Why rapists?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Or Christians and home-schooled kids. Nobody really goes.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I think it’s just a candle lighting ceremony. (pause) How do you already know all this stuff? School hasn’t even started yet. Ruth doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COLLEGE CHAPEL. EVENING
dialogues.text: Tracy lingers outside the building. Kids are going inside She hesitates then decides to bag it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BROADWAY, UPPER WEST SIDE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy walks aimlessly.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy gets a personal sized pizza and a bowl of cereal. S picks up and inspects different items on the dessert tray doesn’t take any.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: In class. Gets a paper back. She gets a B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a starting point - this is what college is for, we're going to teach you how to write and think.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (frowns, to the person next to her.) A “B.” That’s so annoying.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAFETERIA. EVE
dialogues.text: Tracy eats by herself.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MENTAL HEALTH OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy sits in front of a counselor.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Um, I have trouble with procrastinating.

dialogues.speaker: COUNSELOR
dialogues.text: Did you ever think of just getting your work in on time?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Yes, I have thought of that. I have trouble doing it.

dialogues.speaker: COUNSELOR
dialogues.text: Maybe you want to try a little harder?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: OK, thanks. Harder? I’11 try that.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIVERSIDE PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy walks alone.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What comes to mind when you think of the Renaissance?

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy takes notes while a Southern girl talks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think of the Renaissance as being very plush, like a lot of velvet inlaid with jewels, brocades, that kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Thank you... I was actually asking about literature, but that was very nice. Tracy bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DORM HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy is kind of “dressed” for a party. There are a bunch drunk teenagers around. She sees a Friendly Looking Girl:

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Is the party at the end of the hall?

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY LOOKING GIRL
dialogues.text: Did you get an invitation?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY LOOKING GIRL
dialogues.text: Then no.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER GIRL
dialogues.text: She's being a bitch. Yes, it’s down the hall. The Friendly Looking Girl hits the Other Girl and they ru away, laughing. Tracy leaves the way she came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy sits on steps. She’s on the phone with her Mom.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I could be anywhere. It doesn’t even feel like New York. And by trying to participate I’m somehow fitting in even less. Her Mom moves through the kitchen, cleaning, putting thin away.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Aren’t you meeting friends in classes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, nobody meets friends in classes.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. I didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You know the feeling of being at a party where you don’t know anybody? It’s like that the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: That sounds uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: And I can’t go to bars.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Don’t go to bars. Oh, did you get my email with the reading - do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I liked it. I think there is a darker element to what Shakespeare was saying but I liked it.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Good. Your brother is going to be playing guitar with you while you do it - is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I like David’s guitar playing.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (happily) He’s gotten good, right? I’m so excited! It’s Thanksgiving weekend so we'll have a built-in rehearsal dinner on Thursday at the house. It’ll be the first time the two families are all in the same room. Randy, Jim's sister --

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: She's going to make a fig and there’s a fish...and it’s on cracker. That’s one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: We're going to move all the furniture out of the living room and we changed the lyrics to Finiculi Finicula. We did the same thing at Izzy’s 60th but Izzy won't be there so it’1l feel fresh. (exhaling, playful) Oh, Trace...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (playful back) Oh, Stevie.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: You know, I was very unhappy for a very long time. But I’m so glad your Dad and I stayed together until you and your brother were out of school.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I was NOT out of school. You broke up when I was a junior in high school.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: On your way out of the home...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I love you Mom, don’t be worried.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I know, honey. So after you do that, Brooke will read a poem she’s written. I don’t think her brother is doing anything - which hurts my feelings, but I’m trying to be okay with it. (has an idea) You should call Brooke. She’s in New York, you know.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m so bad at calling people I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I hear she’s fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's like thirty living in New York with a life, she doesn’t need to hear from an eighteen year old she’s tenuously connected to. I'd be like why do I want to hang out with you?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: She's going to be your sister, that doesn’t sound tenuous to me. And you have plenty to talk about - you're both doing readings at our wedding.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Aces.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: You aren’t sarcastic don’t pretend to be.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: We hear a student, Nicolette, making a point:

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Nothing is higher than the law. That’s the whole point - Antigone thinks she’s above the law but she’s not - like a celebrity ina car crash or something. Tracy is asleep at the seminar table. Her head hangs heav to one side.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Psst. Hey. Tracy's head jerks up and she opens her sleepy eyes. A bo Tony leans over from two chairs away.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You were asleep.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (wiping drool from her chin) Oh...thanks.  Tracy sits up straighter. She tries to focus on the discussion. Her eyes fall heavy and shut. She’s asleep again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony carries a briefcase. Tracy, deciding to make her fat better, walks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: That was really nice of you... waking me up.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (smiling) It takes a lot of moxie to fall asleep in a twelve person class.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Thanks. I like moxie.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I get it. It’s like I’m so grateful to be here, but why are my parents taking out loans for me to listen to that 18-year-old asshole talk? Tracy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Loans everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I was going go get frozen yogurt, want to come?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yes but... well, I have to get somewhere by five.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Um, it’s embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m submitting a story to the Mobius Literary Society. I have to print it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They only take hard copies which is a kind of pretension I can get behind.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: GET OUT OF TOWN SISTER! I already gave mine! Do you know how you find out if you’re in it?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: They said they’d post a list -

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No. The only people who check the list are people who didn’t get in - they come wake us up at night in our rooms and put pie in our face and then bring us out into the quad and make us sing and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (smiling at the thought) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SOME HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy walks down to a door with Mobius on the glass. Ther a box outside with Submissions written underneath it. A g in a sweater vest sitting cross legged on the ground play jacks stares at her. She fishes into her messenger bag an puts a story in the box. She hurries away. INT. TRACY’S DORM ROOM. NIGHT Tracy lies awake in bed. We hear yelling in the hallway outside her door. Footsteps come close to her door. A shadow underneath. She tenses in great anticipation. The footsteps and chatter continue down the hall. Tracy gets up and opens her door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DORM HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The hall is empty. Bits of pie and crust on the floor. Another door opens at the end of the hall. A Tiny Girl lo out. She and Tracy meet eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FUCK.
dialogues.text: The Tiny Girl retreats into her room. Tracy does the same  INT. TONY’S ROOM. DAY Tony sits on his bed and Tracy sits on the floor. drink screwdrivers.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: They’re self-elected douche bags.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I know, but I wanted to be one of them. I could die then.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too. Both I wanted to be in and I could also then die.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I heard they serve wine and cheese and they all carry breifcases.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I know, when I had my tour here, the guide was one of them and that’s why I wanted to come here.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I heard the pie stuff all night.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: They got the guy next door. He doesn’t even look like a writer. 10. They both Tony indicates a breifcase from the floor. Tracy sees thi

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Do you want to trade stories?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: They both silently read each other's stories. They steal glances at one another.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I liked it!  11.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Thanks - I liked yours too.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So do you want notes?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh, are we - sure...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Okay, I thought the middle part sounded really fake.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s just my impression.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I‘’1l work on that.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Do you have any notes for me?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Um... no.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Great. (thinks for a second) I have a car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. DUSK
dialogues.text: Tracy and Tony drive in the car.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Let’s go to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to leave Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh, why are we in your car then?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. UPPER MANHATTAN, BY THE HUSDON RIVER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy and Tony try to burn his briefcase but it won’t cat fire. They chuck it in the water. They smoke a joint and sit on the roof of a car.  12.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: We look like we’re in a song.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I think the way Aristotle writes about ethics and morality is much closer to how most people think about it. Less like math, more like a story.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DORM ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy, feeling better about herself, cleans the room and talks to her roommate.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I think we should set up a recycling system for our trash. A lot of what we’re throwing out can be recycled. She trips over something on the floor but recovers quickl

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: And Ruth, I think that fan can go in the closet now, it’s 60 degrees out--

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDY ABROAD OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy is filing with some exuberance.

dialogues.speaker: STUDY ABROAD WOMAN
dialogues.text: You seem happy today.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I love filing! It’s satisfying.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. QUAD. EVE
dialogues.text: Tracy is running to get somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Slow down, T! Tracy hits the breaks. It’s Tony. She laughs. But he’s holding Nicolette’s hand (She’s the girl from their class

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Hey.  13.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JJ'S DINER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy sits in a booth by herself eating mozzarella sticks She looks at her phone. Makes a call. Her mother’s voice mail. She hangs up. She scrolls to:

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE CARDINAS
dialogues.text: She quickly presses that name...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE MESSAGE
dialogues.text: You’ve reached Brooke Cardinas. Leave your name and number and I will get back to you at my earliest convenience. Tracy hangs up on the beep. She dips a mozzarella stick i the red sauce and shoves it into her mouth. Her phone rin She's startled.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hi, this Brooke Cardinas. I just got a missed call from this number.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh...sorry. Hi... this is Tracy Fishko, um, my mom is marrying your dad?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You're reading the sonnet.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Right! We’re doing Thanksgiving and then wedding together... Um, I go to college in the city. My mom said I should call you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Have you eaten? Do you want to hang out?  14.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (looks at her near- finished plate) No, I haven’t. OK.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Well, do you know where Times Square is?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TIMES SQUARE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy crosses the crowded street. Brooke is at the top of the TKTS steps. She attempts to w elegantly down the steps. It’s an entrance.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (awkwardly grand) Welcome to the Great White Way. She still hasn’t finished walking the steps. It takes a second. Tracy holds a smile. Finally, Brooke is there:

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Times Square is so crazy.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I don’t know anyone who lives here.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yours truly. I got off the bus from Jersey I thought this was the cool place to live. It’s mother fucking Times Square.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TAXI. LATER
dialogues.text: Brooke lights a cigarette, takes a long drag, passes it t Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Why do you live in New York again?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: College - I go to Barnard - it’s all women uptown - well, “historically” and kind of actually. But there are boys in my classes and stuff. From Columbia.  15.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You gay?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No. The Columbia girls do their best to make us feel inferior. Which it’s like “I already do.”

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: That’s stupid. Don’t feel inferior.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You're right, that is stupid. It’s the best someone has made her feel in a long time or Maybe ever.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BACKSTAGE AT A MUSIC CLUB. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Brooke, wearing an orange VIP sticker on her suede jacket affixes an identical sticker to Tracy’s shirt.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t go to college.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh. OK.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I’m an autodidact. Do you know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: That word is one of the things I self-taught myself. CUT TO: Brooke is pulled up onstage to sing, she tries to act like she doesn’t want to and then does it. When she dances while she sings it’s a person who is pretending to free.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Brooke, Tracy and members of the band enter one of those secret bars, through the back of a pizza shop.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SECRET BAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy drinks a fancy cocktail.  16.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It has mint! CUT TO: Brooke and Tracy dance with the guys.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (dancing) What’s going on at college?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (also dancing) I don’t know, everyone’s really excited about the frozen yogurt machine in the student center.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I watched my mother die.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I was with my mother while she died.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I don’t know any dead people.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: That’s cool about the frozen yogurt machine. Everyone I love dies.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMSBURG PARTY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Brooke and Tracy enter some party in Williamsburg. The hostess hugs Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I heard you’re opening a restaurant!? WTF?!

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMSBURG BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Brooke and Tracy are in a closet - Brooke is going throug while Tracy watches her.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: This bitch stole my favorite pants - they’re in here somewhere - she thinks I don’t know but I know everything. They're red.  17.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (vaguely) I’1l look here. Tracy starts going through the closet.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: People are always taking my shit. My ex-friend and nemesis, Mamie- Claire, stole my ideas AND my fiance.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: She took this T-shirt idea that I had, started a company fucking sold it to J. Crew so there is that. She’s one of those people who doesn’t have any good ideas for her own life so she just steals all of mine. And then she LITERALLY stole my cats.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What were the T-shirts?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Just really hard looking flowers.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh my God! I bought one of those T- shirts!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, flowers with like skulls and shit. Daggers.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: That’s a great one.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: My fiance, Dylan, was super sexy. And so rich. But I wasn’t going to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: So...wait, you broke up with Dylan? I thought she stole him?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: And I never looked back. He cried so hard. Like, whiney.  18. She does an impression:

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: “Where are you going?” (back to herself) I was being real, but Mamie-Claire then goes and marries him. They live in Greenwich, Connecticut in some big gross house. Do you know that place?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Greenwich, grossville.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Right? Living off of his riches and my T-shirt idea.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (instant disciple) I hate them.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I actually pity them. They have no more dreams. Tracy holds up a pair of red pants, triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: These?!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I want to MARRY you! She grabs the pants, stuffs them in her purse and then ge out of the closet.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMSBURG PARTY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Brooke makes out with Nate, the singer. Tracy is trying n to watch. Another band member takes a picture on his iPho

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Must we all document ourselves all the time? MUST WE?!

dialogues.speaker: INT. VESELKA. LATE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy and Brooke eat pierogis in the mostly empty diner.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Is he your boyfriend? The bassist?  19.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Nate? No! My beau, Stavros, is in Greece right now. Betting against the country or something gross. Don’t tell anyone that.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (dead serious) I won’t. I’m good at keeping secrets. You’ll learn that about me.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: He’s one of those people I hate except I’m in love with him. I’ve been to a Greek Orthodox Easter and I could totally see myself getting married in that kind of church. She knocks her head for wood.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You got a honey?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Nah, there’s this one guy, we got rejected together...but he’s got a girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: They all have girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Actually I think he met me and then he got a girlfriend. (pause) This summer, at my job, one guy just sucked on my boobs all night.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (thinking aloud) My restaurant should do a pierogi. Fusion pierogi. You like yours?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (nods, stuffing a pierogi in her mouth) This is my second dinner. Brooke takes out her phone and types something.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (putting her phone back) Just a quick tweet on Twitter. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am VERY into social media. You have to market yourself. If you don’t know what you’re selling, no one will know how to buy it.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What are you selling?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: So many things. I don’t tweet all of it. Like here are two ideas that are not on the internet. If I did a cabaret, it would be called “High Standards” and I'd sing all the standards.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Would you sing them in a higher pitch?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No, it wouldn’t be about - it’s about principles, those kinds of high standards - like one of those “string of pearls that’s why I’ma single gal” kind of show.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: That’s clever.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: The second idea is a television show, which I’ve read is the new novel, about a woman who is a government worker by day and a self- invented super hero by night, but like the essence of AMERICA. It’1l be it’s own mythology. I think maybe it’1ll be called Mistress America.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: That sounds like she’s America’s girl on the side.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hey, I don’t know, okay, I’m not positive, these are just some ideas.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Me too! I’m sorry, I don’t know anything, I was just throwing something out there.  21. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (an idea) We need a sleep-over party.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BROOKE'S APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Books piled on the floor. Lots of drawings pinned to the wall. One framed piece of real art.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: This apartment is technically zoned commercial but that’s fake.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’s so stylish.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Fuck, I know, I freelance as an interior decorator. You know the Bowery Hotel?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh my God, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Well, if you walk about a block south. There’s a laser hair removal center that’s very hip. I did the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I’m leaving here in January anyway, moving to the East side if you can believe it. That’s where Stavros lives. I’m going to redo his place too. Brooke flops on her bed. Tracy lies on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I want to write short stories.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh, me too! Not short stories, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I got rejected by the Lit Society. I’m so suggestible, like because I got rejected I think I can’t be a writer.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you make your own Lit Society?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I wish. Mobius is a big deal at school.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You've got other stories.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (smiling) Maybe I’1l write something else and resubmit. (falling asleep, eyes closed) That was really funny when we were doctors.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I need to cut all the negative people out of my life. I just wasn’t brought up that way.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Thank you Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome Baby Tracy. INT. BROOKE’S APARTMENT. NEXT MORNING Brooke is on the phone with Stavros:

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: My sweetheart I miss you so much - I can’t wait for you to see the chairs I’ve picked out - we start renovation Monday! It’s so exciting. I’ve been going there just to sit in the mess I love it so much. Tracy wakes up a little with the noise.  23.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Right. Did you see the lease it was 400 pages! I wish you would just come home already so I can suck your dick in our new restaurant! She pads into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (to Tracy) Can you start the coffee, please?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (looking at the coffee maker) I don’t know how...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (a little sharply) Yes, you do. Don’t be incompetent. If you spent two seconds with a coffee maker you'd figure it out. You just aren’t trying hard enough. Brooke retreats into the hall, still talking to her boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Um, where are you going.

dialogues.speaker: TO WATCH
dialogues.text: (to the phone) Are you still there?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Sorry. Are you... mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Tracy and Brooke drink coffee at her table/desk.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: We have four investors including me. I’m what you call a principal investor. Stavros is putting in my share - but I insisted that it be my assets on the line because I want him to know I have skin in the game. I’11 pay him back of course once we start making a profit.  24.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: We never went to restaurants growing up - it wasn’t part of our lives.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (immediately offended) That’s a shitty thing to say to me.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean - I know people will come to yours. (trying to contextualize) It’s so weird to think that every restaurant I see is the result of some person going “I think I want to start a restaurant.”

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: That’s not weird. That’s everything. Tracy starts to write something down in a notebook. Brook is curious:

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m actually... it’s embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m writing down what I said.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You are noting yourself?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah... I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I’ve noticed something about myself that would make a good character in a story.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?  25.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: But I’m going to save it in case I want to use it in something I write.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TIMES SQUARE. MORNING
dialogues.text: The commercial streets have that peculiar weekend morning vibe. Tracy is in her outfit from the night before. Brook is in full workout clothes.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: High five, sister. That was an AMAZING night.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was... (blurts it out) The best of my life.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (looking at her phone) I gotta go. Brooke abruptly hugs her and leaves. Tracy watches her go for one second and then also turns to go. She’s disappoin but she doesn’t know why. INT. TRACY’S DORM ROOM. MORNING Tracy enters and goes right to her computer. Tracy is typing very quickly, still in her jacket, her ba still on her shoulder. She hesitates, trying to remember something.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What did she...say? Talking while she types.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Right! “He’s one of those people that I hate except I’m in love with him.”

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (still sleeping) Shut up please. CUT TO: Brooke Cardinas being typed into a Google search.  26.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Meadow DeRiggi lived exactly how a young woman should live who wants to spend her youth well. CUT TO: Brooke’s Twitter page. Random photos of Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She did everything and nothing and spent time like I always mean to - purposefully. CLOSE on Tracy’s short story. CLOSE on a Society page photo. CLOSE on Brooke’s Soul Cycle Teacher bio.

dialogues.speaker: EXT./INT. PIZZA PARLOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy tries to go to the secret bar, can’t get in.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Her beauty was that rare kind that made you want to look more like yourself not like her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT./INT. MUSIC CLUB. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy gets in, but it’s not a good band and there aren’t lot of people there.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She sang with the band and knew everyone and didn't owe anyone anything and couldn't pay up even if she did.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOWNTOWN STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy sees a blonde in red pants. She brightens. As she gets closer, it’s not Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Being around Meadow was like being in New York City - it made you want to find life, not hide from it.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Sorry.  27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s OK.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COLLEGE LIBRARY. DAY
dialogues.text: Tony and Nicolette and Tracy sit at a study table.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Where were you last night, did you get my texts?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: You text her? You texted her?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: About work.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I went to check out this downtown band at this downtown bar. Two freshmen girls approach.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Do you guys know how long you’1l need this table?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: A long time, dude.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (sighs) Fine. They leave.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Who were you with?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Myself.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (to Tony) When you said you were checking the scores, were you texting her? Are you sexting?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’s a place my sister showed me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You don’t have a sister.  28.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I do. Or I will. When my mom gets married at Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just text her a picture of your balls.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nicolette! Tracy smooths over some stapled pages from her bag. We se the title: Mistress America.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It's a new story I wrote. I’m going to resubmit to the Lit Society.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Wait, you wrote another one already? You printed it on onion skin?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You can read it if you want. Here-- She hands him a copy - he looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Nicolette) Tracy writes about fighter pilots.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m past that stuff now. This one is more autobiographical documentary.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: OK. I'd totally give you notes.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t want notes -- but I thought about it and I actually do have notes for you.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh...sure.  29.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You write like you are imitating someone who is free and wild and it is so WEIRD because you aren’t at all and it made me uncomfortable and I think it would make EVERYONE uncomfortable. And also, stop trying to be funny because you aren’t funny so it just adds to the awkwardness. And it could be 30% shorter, easy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (unsure) OK. Thanks. Tracy gets up and leaves. Passes the freshmen girls.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’s open, bitches. They don’t need it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SOME HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy returns to the door with Mobius on the glass. The s guy in a sweater vest is whittling a piece of wood. He bl on it as he whittles. Tracy places her story in the Submissions box. She hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SOUL CYCLE STUDIO. DAY
dialogues.text: Brooke is in the front of the classroom, on a bike with a headphone and a bandana. Tracy enters, wearing jeans and a button down. Brooke smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (too loudly) Hey Baby Tracy! Brooke indicates a bike with a nod of her head. Tracy sha her head emphatically: No. Brooke nods, Yes. CUT TO: Tracy is on a bike sweating an uncomfortable amou

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (to her cycling class)

dialogues.speaker: EVERYTHING AM I RIGHT
dialogues.text: (and now in a low voice) I know not enough people have told you that you’re amazing. I know that that’s true.  30. Everyone loves her, she’s sort of great as a cycling instructor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy is really sweaty, still.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You did great!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I feel like I just went swimming in my clothes.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I’m glad you came.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You are?!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Shit, I have to shower and change, I’m late for an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SALON. DAY
dialogues.text: Brooke gets her hair blown out - Tracy sits beside her an looks at Brooke in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: This air conditioning is making me freezing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MIDTOWN STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Brooke, in a conservative blouse and suit, pearl earrings heels, holding a briefcase walks with Tracy in her jeans. She towers over her. (Midnight Cowboy shot.)

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. MIDTOWN RESTAURANT. DAY
dialogues.text: They stop outside the restaurant. Brooke is suddenly very nervous. She smooths down her blouse, her hair.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (pulling down the sides of her skirt) God, I’m packed into this pencil skirt. How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You look beautiful.  31.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: But do I look professional? (pause) I get really nervous with the investors. I’m usually fine with wealthy people, it’s just when I need something from them.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No, it’s the opposite - they need you and your restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Stavros usually does this stuff. Maybe I shouldn’t do it. I’m not good at it.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (sincerely) I think you can do anything. Everything. Brooke nods.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Right. Kind and fearless. She goes inside. CUT TO: Tracy watches through the window. Brooke sits amongst three men in suits and another powerful looking w in a suit. She makes them laugh. CUT TO: Brooke meets Tracy outside. Brooke looks relieved

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It’s amazing how much of business is just stating the same things over and over again.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Your body language looked very self- confident.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Thanks. You make me feel really... Smart. Tracy beams.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Wanna see it?  32.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EMPTY RESTAURANT SPACE, BROOKLYN. DAY
dialogues.text: Brooke shows Tracy the space. During the scene, Brooke is changing out of her “lawyer outfit” into her “tutoring outfit” - skinny jeans, T-shirt and Converse.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (gesturing) The front part would be like a shop during the day - like a general store or a really nice bodega - candy from Europe - on Monday we start demo and we open in April. She knocks her head for “wood.” She leads Tracy through t back -

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: We'd also have cooking classes. Maybe cut hair. It would be like a community center and restaurant and store all in one. It would be the place that you would, like, LOVE to be. I wish I had something like this when I was growing up.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah, suburban New Jersey isn’t great with this kind of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Each plate would be different. Let me show you.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Can I be a waitress here? Brooke opens a box.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: See! Look at all these plates!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (taking in the whole thing) Holy shit you have a lot of plates.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I started collecting them so long ago - I didn’t know why and now I have a why! Tracy's been touching all of them.  33.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: This is going to be a great restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I know!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Are you going to cook, too?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) I‘1l help create the menu and pitch in when needed. I’m not trained, but I’m an enthusiastic home cook. I always used to cook with my Mom. That’s the name of the restaurant. Mom's. Possessive.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (trying it out) “Let’s go to Mom’s for dinner.” Yeah, it totally works. (tries again) Can I be a waitress here?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I want the whole deal - I want the dead-on-my-feet-wake-up-and-I 'm- forty. I’ve spent my whole life chasing after things and knocking at doors and I’m tired of running towards people. I want to be the place that people COME to. I want to make a home for all the knockers and runners - I’m good at that. I'm happy with that. I keep the hearth. That’s a word, right? Hearth?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BROOKLYN APARTMENT. LATER
dialogues.text: Brooke is going in to tutor. The final thing she does is on her fake glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Don’t I look like a cute smart graduate student?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah!  34.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I tutor junior high because I didn’t get high enough SAT scores to do SAT tutoring, but you make way more money doing SAT. So, I’m taking the SAT’s AGAIN so I can make inroads into that racket.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’ve always been a good test taker.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: None of this will be necessary when the restaurant is up and running, but I’m good that way, curating my employment. Brooke is rifling through her purse.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: So, um, should I - just wait here or...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh! I thought you had to go back to school.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Right. I should....

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Do you want to stay?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I mean, if you don’t mind...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’d invite you in but Peggy's Mom just got institutionalized for bi-polar disorder and shit’s pretty real upstairs. Tutoring is like 60% middle school math and 40% I know too much about them.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: That’s okay, then, I’1ll just go - Brooke hands her keys, not listening to her.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You remember where my apartment is, go there.  35.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (thrilled) Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: And pick up some pasta, I’11 cook.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What kind of-- But Brooke is ringing the bell.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUBWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy excitedly looks at the keys in her hand, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (into answering machine) Mom - hey - are you there? SHIT.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GROCERY STORE. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy stands in the pasta aisle, looking at all the diffe brands of pastas. She picks one up and then another. She’ on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (leaving message) I just wanted to know - what kind of pasta would you buy if you wanted to buy a nice pasta? - Like the brand? If you get this can you call me back right away? She hangs ups. CUT TO: Tracy is on the phone with Tony, scanning the bra

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: This one is like bowties? Get that? CUT TO: Tony and Nicolette together in his bed. Nicolette angry.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Do they have regular spaghetti?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Is that pasta the same way as the others?  36.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (to Tony) Is this some sex game?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (covering the phone) No! We're actually talking about pasta.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (sullen) Why don’t you just put pasta up her pussy?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nicolette! Seriously! CUT TO: Tracy still in the store.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’1l get that and I'll get the bowties. And there’s shells--

dialogues.speaker: INT. BROOKLYN APARTMENT. SAME TIME
dialogues.text: Brooke is sitting with a thirteen year old girl, working set of pre-algebra problems.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: X can be anything, any number, that is what’s CRAZY about X.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Then why isn’t it just a number.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Because X doesn’t roll like that, because X can’t be pinned down! It can be ANYTHING and we have to figure out what it is - crazy bastard. Peggy giggles and starts writing.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Maybe you could spend the night?  37.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh, honey, I’m sorry. I’m math only. INT. BROOKE’S APARTMENT. LATE AFTERNOON Tracy unpacks an enormous amount of pasta onto the counte

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I remembered looking across the river at the unblinking lights of Manhattan apartments, wondering who lived there. She touches items, looks at things, takes notes. Takes a tiny airplane and puts it in her pocket. Flips through so SAT prep books.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was part of it now, on the fifth floor, in a temporary commercial apartment. There was our castle. Our fortress. Yes! This is how I imagined it would be: college, New York, my whole entire life. Brooke cooks while Tracy watches her and hands her things

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But outside the windows I could hear the hot sound of jackhammers taking the city apart. Brooke and Tracy eat spaghetti carbonara.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In New York neighborhoods change as quickly as the weather. Or maybe it’s the other way around.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TIMES SQUARE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy and Brooke walk together arm and arm.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I couldn’t warn Meadow. By the time I noticed it, it was already too late.  38.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s a bar bar, they’re there to get drunk. Or at least Brooke is. Brooke looks at something on her phone. Laughs Holds it out for Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Nate dropped a gram on Instagram. That means a picture. Tracy smiles but less assuredly.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’s you guys kissing.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It’s already got eighty likes. All his other recent pictures have like fifty likes. The extra thirty must be because of me.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It looks like a really stylish breathmint ad.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I know! Bob’s a real shutterbug. He made his own app. (to the bartender) Put it on... (very considered) ...this card.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Did these two drinks earn me another free hot dog? The Bartender nods, hands her a hotdog.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (ve: the drinks) Drop it in the glass and chug it. I'd love to get into the app business. I think my Dad met your Mom on the internet.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah, on a free dating website. They didn’t even pay.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Gross. But also I guess it’s pro forma now? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Tracy nods) My Dad’s so strange. I’m sure he’s making her convert to Catholicism, right?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah! What’s that about?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: He’s real Catholic now. It’s so boring, but it happened when my mom got sick. She was never that into it. He’s a geologist.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I know. I had never met a geologist before.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It’s weird that someone who studies rocks can be really into Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What did your Mom do?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: She was a special education teacher.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: That’s so nice.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: She was really good at it. I still don’t like retarded jokes. Wanna see a picture of her? She hands Tracy her phone. Tracy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t look like you but she has your expression, you know? A woman around Brooke’s age approaches:

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hi -

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (looking up) Hello.  40.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hi, I don’t know if you remember me, we went to high school together? Anna Wheeler.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh YEAH!

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I was in the chorus of Anything Goes.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Holy SHIT! Yeah! What are you doing in the city? You live here?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, I’m in Tenafly. My fiance and I went to go see a show.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Other Desert Cities.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s a piece of shit. And the girl who replaced the lead is AWFUL. (to Tracy) I used to run around with her. Well, she was older, is older.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We loved it.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Let me buy you guys a drink what are you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You know, that’s okay - (gathering herself) I just wanted to tell you because I never had the courage to do it when I was actually in high school - you really hurt my feelings.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (laughs) What?  41.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You don’t remember?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No! What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That thing: “yep, bitter”?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (still genial) I don’t know what the FUCK you’re talking about! I always liked you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You and your friend Abe -

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: Tracy horks her hot dog.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You guys used to do this thing where you’d walk up to me and touch my skin and then like taste it and think for a minute and then say “yep, bitter.” And then laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Right! We did do that, didn’t we? We were weird.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I was standing right there, every single time you did it. It was really mean, and I just wanted to say - fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Whoa. WHOA.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: The way you treated me really messed me up for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Everyone is an asshole in high school!

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You made a lot of people feel bad. Not just me.  42.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for the thirteen year old girl that was you but I’m not sorry for you now.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We were seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: If I was thirteen I'd apologize to you but seeing as both of us are...in our twenties. I don’t see the need.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I just turned thirty.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You're a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Why?! You’re the one who hung onto a grudge for this fucking long! Do you know I didn’t even recognize you? I don’t say that to be mean, that’s the way it should be.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (tearing up) You are the same. Malevolent.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You WERE bitter. That’s probably why it hurt you so much. Because it was true.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (now crying) I wish all bad things on you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (calling after) I don’t on you because I don’t CARE! And neither should you!  43.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THEATER DISTRICT. LATER
dialogues.text: Brooke drunk. cold - became and Tracy are wandering home. Tracy looks really Brooke is still furious at the woman. It has turned in the time they were in the bar their coats suddenly not enough.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: That’s so dramatic! What a drama queen. (scoffs) I can’t believe she lives in fucking Tenafly. What is she rich now? How dare she talk to me that way and be rich?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: When I was in junior high, this girl Tara Podwoski used to pull my hair and call me a cunt hunter.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t do what that girl said. I just wasn’t brought up that way. I should call Abe and see if he remembers. Brooke pulls out her phone.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Maybe do it later?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (nods, puts the phone away ) Yeah. I was so popular in high school but I didn’t try AT ALL. People just wanted to be friends with me. I didn’t even care about that stuff. When someone told me I was popular I was like “Really? Weird.”

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: That’s why you were popular. The popular kids never care. I cared too much. Like if you want to know all the popular kids’ business, ask an unpopular kid. They always know everything. Because they are the ones who really pay attention.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I’m going to shorten that, punch it up, and turn it into a tweet. Tracy throws up. Brooke immediately holds her hair back a comforts her.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh no! Did I feed you too much liquor?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’1l be okay.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: We should get you a cab.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Can I...would it be OK if I slept over again?

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT HALLWAY. LATER
dialogues.text: Tracy leans against the door-jam while Brooke tries to op the apartment door.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m pretty sure college is supposed to be more fun than I’m having.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Damn it...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m kind of attractive.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Argh...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I might be up for another drink. Is that crazy?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Fuck ME!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What’s happening?  45.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I FUCKING DON’T BELIEVE THIS SHIT MOTHER FUCKING SHIT. She kicks the door and screams.

dialogues.speaker: THE GODDAMN LOCKS ARE CHANGED
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Brooke and Tracy head down a flight of stairs. CUT TO: Brooke rings a buzzer. A handsome African American answers. Nods hello.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hey, Kareem, can we use your fire escape?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIRE ESCAPE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Brooke climbs up to her apartment window in bare-feet. Tr looks up from below, holding Brooke’s shoes.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Shit. I thought I left this window open.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I might have closed it.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Why?!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I didn’t want you to get robbed. INT. KAREEM’S APARTMENT. NIGHT Tracy and Kareem sit on a couch waiting. Outside on the f escape Brooke is yelling on her phone.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Stavros saw a picture of her kissing a musician. (pause) Stavros is her boyfriend. He told the super that Brooke was living in a commercial space. Is your place zoned commercial?

dialogues.speaker: KAREEM
dialogues.text: Yeah.  46.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I hope he doesn’t rat on you. They hear louder shouting from the fire escape. The windo opens. Brooke steps inside. Her make up is smeared. She’s been crying.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: He’s pulling out of the restaurant. INT. TRACY’S DORM ROOM. NIGHT Tracy is on the bed, Brooke is on the floor in a makeshif bed. Tracy’s roommate, Ruth, looks annoyed and impressed. It’s dark.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I hope Stavros doesn’t rat out Kareem.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: If I don’t have this money...my partners will bail, they’re in because Stavros was in. And they can go after my savings, everything... Rich people will take any excuse not to spend money - you can just see it in their eyes that they don’t really want to share life with you.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Rich people always give out bad Halloween candy.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: The contractors need 20 thousand on Monday. And then there’s the key fee, that’s fifty - and then there are all these industrial refrigerators coming for another fifteen... I need whatever that equals by Monday. He was in for 200 thousand. Oh my fucking god.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Isn’t there someone else you can ask to invest?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I already hit up every rich person I knew the first time around. This was well thought through, Tracy.  47.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, it’s such a good investment. I’d put money in if I had it.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Do you secretly have money?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No. My mom never worked and I think my Dad was always kind of mad at her for that... but my parents divorce was way easier than this.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (viciously) That's because they stopped caring about life just entirely, it’s not the same thing. My Mom died so don’t even fucking start with me about your pain. Ruth pipes up:

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: My uncle died.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Shut up, RUTH. Brooke sits up.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I need some answers.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (immediately) I’m coming.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WAITING AREA. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Brooke and Tracy are waiting on a couch in an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I’m going to be worse off now than I was before I started trying to achieve stuff.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I know what it is to want things.  48.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No, you don’t. You can’t really know what it is to want things until you're at least thirty. And then with each passing year it gets more because the want is bigger and the possibility is less. Like how each passing year of your life feels faster because it is a smaller portion of your total life. Like that but in reverse. Everything becomes pure want.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: OK, Brooke, I’m ready... CUT TO: Brooke sits in front of a man, 40’s, in his apartment. Tracy is next to Brooke looking at a chart.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: Spirit says seek out an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: Someone who hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Just tell me exactly what to do.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: Spirit says something about fabric.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (suddenly) It’s your friend - Mamie-Claire? The fabric is the T-shirts! Brooke shoots Tracy a look.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: And, I see flowers.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Hard looking flowers!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Please, Tracy. (to the psychic) Mamie-Claire is my enemy.  49.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: Yes, Spirit says you have unfinished business with this woman.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No, no, it’s finished. Tell Spirit it’s finished.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: What happened with Mamie-Claire?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: She totally screwed Brooke over. She married her fiance and stole her idea.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: TRACY! Shut up. (to the Psychic) I never looked back.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: I am seeing this, yes. I am seeing... trees...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You said she lives in Connecticut! There are trees in Connecticut. The Psychic looks at Brooke for affirmation.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Well, to be fair, there are trees pretty much everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You have to listen to Spirit! Mamie-Claire can give you the money! Hi-ho Greenwich!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (to the Psychic) Really? Can we get confirmation? Is Spirit sure of this?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: The young one is right.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (re: Tracy) She’s not that young. Ten...ten to twelve years younger, we are contemporaries, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must seek out Mamie-Claire.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I’m so annoyed with Spirit.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: The path isn’t against you it’s just the path.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Right. I don’t want to be petty... I just wasn’t brought up that way. She's my nemesis, but she does owe me.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: This has been a heavy weight on you. Sometimes you have to go back to go front.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Fuck this parade. I’m going to Greenwich.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: We're going.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You ready for this, squirt? It’s going to get ugly.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (smiling) I’m ready.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Great. How are we going to get there? INT. TONY’S CAR. DAY Brooke sits in the back seat with Nicolette. Tracy looks her phone and gives directions to Tony in the front.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I really don’t like to leave Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (to Tony) You're going to want to take the Merrit Parkway.  51.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I‘1l bet Dylan is still in love with me. Marrying Mamie-Claire is like buying a cashmere sweater from Old Navy. Tony looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Even if he’s not, this is a great investment. And don’t forget she still owes you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It’s win win. Because I’m sure he still loves me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) I’m not driving you to Connecticut to break up a marriage. I should be in my room reading Nichomachean Ethics.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Calm down rich boy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m not rich.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yes you are you have a car.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, I’m not - my dad is a mechanic. He and my uncle have a body shop. I have this car because it was something that he could give me.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (to Tracy) Sorry, I think I offended your boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: He’s not her boyfriend, he’s mine.”

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (to Nicolette) Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Because Tracy made Tony drive you.  52.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: But why did you come?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: I... I had a bad experience with adultery before. My last boyfriend committed adultery while we were together and I just don’t like to let my boyfriends get too far.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: ADULTERY? Why the fuck does it matter? You are all eighteen! Where is this old-person morality coming from? There is no “cheating” when you’re eighteen. You should all be touching each other all the time. CUT TO: Tracy zones out.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Do you ever get that feeling when you are on a car trip that you never want to get where you’re going. That you never want it to end. Everyone is silent, thinking about it. Nicolette reaches to playfully touch Tony’s hair. Tony freaks.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nicolette! You SCARED THE FUCKING

dialogues.speaker: SHIT OUT OF ME
dialogues.text: Nicolette sits back, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (trying to make it up) Sweety, it’s...nice, it’s just I’m driving.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GAS STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: Tony fills the tank while Nicolette gives him a back rub. Tracy stretches her legs. Brooke comes out of the store eating a Slim Jim.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (passing Tracy) You should be with him, not that goth housewife.  53.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No, he knew me, he chose her.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Only because you let him. You have to chase down the things you want.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I was just going to let it go.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (considering her) Sometimes I don’t know if you are a zen master or a sociopath.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m just normal! (taking the bait) I‘1l give him a back rub he won't soon forget. Brooke gives her a half hug/squeeze, jokingly.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You don’t give shit, do you? I’m so glad you’re on my team. Brooke wanders from the car and stretches. Tracy watches. Tracy watches Brooke, bent over, brushing out her hair fr the bottom, fixing her makeup.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But the very things that had worked so well for Meadow up until then had started turning and fading. She had no other skills, no other way of dealing with the world. In one instant her behaviors turned from charming to borderline hysteric. People could feel her failure coming. She smelled of something rotten. Her youth had died and she was dragging around the decaying carcass. CUT TO: Entering Greenwich, Connecticut. The houses flyin by become bigger and bigger. More elegant. This is the wealthy.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had somehow become the pallbearer.  54.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m trying to find Mamie-Claire’s address. Does she have a different last name?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I have a visual memory of it. It’s kind of photographic.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh you’ve been here?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Well, I kind of stalked them once. I was so pissed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GREENWICH, CT. DAY
dialogues.text: They all get out of the car. Brooke squints.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yep, this is it. She starts to walk up to the house. Everyone follows her.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh we're all going? Okay, we look crazy, but maybe that’s good. The four of them walk up to the house and ring the doorbe Wait. A man answers, forties.

dialogues.speaker: 40'S MAN
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hi, yes, I was wondering - is Mamie- Claire or Dylan in... I’m an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: 40'S MAN
dialogues.text: Wrong house.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh, which is their house? I never come here! I live in New York.

dialogues.speaker: 40'S MAN
dialogues.text: I’1l take you there. The 40’s Man leading the way, the four of them troop over another house, across the big lawn and through some bushe and trees.  55. He walks up to the door, rings the bell. Brooke, Tracy, Tony and Nicolette stand just behind him, of sight. A woman opens the door. It’s Mamie-Claire.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Harold.

dialogues.speaker: 40'S MAN
dialogues.text: What do you think I was doing last night?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t know Harold, watching kiddie porn?

dialogues.speaker: 40'S MAN
dialogues.text: NO! Listening to you and your husband shouting and not sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: So sorry we interfered with your kiddie-porn.

dialogues.speaker: 40'S MAN
dialogues.text: I am a PEDIATRICIAN.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Obviously!

dialogues.speaker: 40'S MAN
dialogues.text: Next time I hear decibel levels like I did I’m calling the cops. That is a promise. He stalks off.

dialogues.speaker: 40'S MAN
dialogues.text: (annoyed, to Brooke) This is the house. Brooke jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: What - what are you doing here? Who are these people?  56.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (presenting everyone one by one) Tracy's Mom is marrying my Dad. Tony drove. Nicolette is jealous. Then a lot of unnecessary hand shaking takes place.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I’m Mamie-Claire. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Nicolette.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Mamie-Claire. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Tony - and wait, no don’t tell me - Mamie-Claire? Mamie-Claire ignores the joke, turns back to Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I thought we weren’t speaking.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Right, I want to change that... And I have something I really need to talk to you and Dylan about...

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Dylan isn’t here.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) He volunteers at a retirement community. I’m in the middle of... (hesitates again) It’s a thing we do. It’s like a party.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: That’s okay.  57.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No... it’s not... (getting flustered, then clarifying firmly) It’s not for you to say okay, it’s for me to say okay.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: We'll wait in the car.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No, that’s weird.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: People wait in cars.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (sighs) You and your... “posse” can hang out in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Mamie-Claire leads them past pregnant and just-pregnant w who discuss Faulkner’s “The Hamlet.

dialogues.speaker: PREGNANT WOMAN
dialogues.text: I think the way Faulkner uses language is akin to the way the modernist painters were using paint - exploring the reality of words or paint itself -

dialogues.speaker: PREGNANT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Only Faulkner was interested in how that happens while characters are ACTUALLY trying to communicate, not just drawing attention to the constructedness of the novel.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to himself) Holy shit those pregnant women are super-smart. Everyone is impressed. INT. MAMIE-CLAIRE'’S KITCHEN. DAY Mamie-Claire puts down snacks for the “posse.”

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t know if you're hungry, but this is for if you’re hungry.  58.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: This place is amazing.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Brooke frowns, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It’s really fucking nice.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Would it be OK if we sat in on your discussion?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (confused) Yeah, I guess. This week’s book is Faulkner's “The Hamlet.” Followed by a kind of junky biography of Derrida, but it’s fun.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Tight. He and Nicolette follow Mamie-Claire back into the living room. Tracy looks at a picture of Mamie-Claire on a boat, Brook leans down and whispers to her:

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Apparently, she got recruited by Tufts for crew and went but then NEVER did it. I mean, that’s the kind of person she is, just sly and shitty.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I would do that if I could. I wasn’t good at sports.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I would too, but it wouldn’t be like my CHARACTER. It would just be something I did.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: When does that become the same thing?  59.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know! CUT TO: Brooke and Tracy wait in the kitchen. They’ve eat all the snacks. They’re bored. Brooke looks at her phone.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you could change the font setting - I hate Helvetica. Mamie-Claire enters and places plates in the sink. Brooke stands immediately.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You look amazing.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Why are all these kids with you?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: They aren't “kids.” If they’re kids, we are.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (piping up, to Mamie- Claire) I’m an associate and her almost- sister.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I really need to talk to you...

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Okay, how long do you think you'll need with me, because -

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: How long will Dylan be “giving back” at the old folks home? I’d also like to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: We're both very busy, I have an appointment after this...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Mamie-Claire, that’s stupid, you aren’t REALLY busy.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Yes! I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tracy) Remember this truth: It’s only people who don’t have jobs and don’t have anything to do that are always fucking BUSY. Like what are you DOING?!

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: We started a community farm. We have goats.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (wandering in) Goats are more sustainable. They’re smaller. Tony behind her.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Than what?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Cows.

dialogues.speaker: PREGNANT WOMAN
dialogues.text: (pokes her head into the kitchen) Um, Mamie-Claire?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I have to see my guests out. 60. Tony and Nicolette follow Mamie-Claire to the kitchen doo

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I want to say goodbye to Karen.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Do you have a crush on Karen now?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: She’s seven months pregnant!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Why do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Nicolette and Tony are looking at a chess set. women are leaving. Mamie-Claire is seeing her Pregnant guests out.  61.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Mamie-Claire) Mamie-Claire, can me and Nicolette play with your chess set?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (confused by who he even is) Yes. A pregnant woman sits by the door with her bag in her lap

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Everything OK, Karen?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m just waiting for my husband. He’s late to pick me up.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You want to play chess with us?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (to Tony, wanting attention) You have to teach me.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: No, he’ll be here any minute. She checks her phone. Clearly nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Mamie-Claire comes back into the kitchen cleaning up.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Sorry, I got started on the wrong foot there - I meant to say, I’ve been missing you as a friend and...

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: She has a very exciting business opportunity for you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: And I wanted to bring it to you and Dylan as a peace offering. I really think you’re going to want to hear about this...  62.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: The last time I saw you you were hiding in the bushes and then you started incoherently yelling at me and my husband about how we had ruined your life and the time before that you were throwing up at my wedding.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Which is why I am bringing you this exciting business opportunity! Mamie-Claire goes into the dining room. Tracy nods at her like “keep going!” They follow Mamie-Claire.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I would like to offer you a share in a restaurant I’m starting.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Because it is all set up and ready to go and I already have the ability to draw a crowd and it'll just be... perfect. You'll love it. So will Dylan.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: There are lots of other investors.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: But not so many that it would dilute your investment.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
