dialogues.text: So why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Well, there was a slight snafu with one of our people which allowed a very coveted spot to open up, which I am offering only to you guys... Mamie-Claire considers.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It’s not really a good time for me to get involved with a business...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Why?  63.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: We're trying to have a baby...

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You'll never regret it.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Karen.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It’s just money, you don’t have to do any of the work, you just get the glory and the profit and the satisfaction of being involved with something awesome.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t think Dylan would buy into it. We recently lost money purchasing taxi cab medallions.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to overstep my bounds here but I think you might be wrong - when is he coming back?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I really need to focus on having children - this isn’t part of what I need to focus on. No, just... Can I just say no? Brooke gets furious.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No, you cannot “just say no.” Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t need a why.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: The money means NOTHING to you! Look at all this shit, this house that patio furniture. You can spare it, you wouldn’t even miss it!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: And it really would make a profit!

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No. You can’t make me.  64.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yes, I can because you OWE me.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (trying to stop her) Um, Brooke...

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (evenly) I don’t owe you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: For Dylan because that was just skanky but really for the T-shirts - you stole my T-shirt idea and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I did not steal your idea. It was my idea and you were there when I had it.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No! That’s so wrong - I remember like the minute I said “what if this flower was, like, TOUGH.” And then we started riffing but I SAID IT FIRST.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (calmly) No, you didn’t. Brooke screams.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You are so annoying when you get calm voice! Brooke storms off into the backyard. Stops short when she sees two cats.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Are these my fucking cats?!

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: They're mine. I paid for their cat surgery so they’re mine.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Did my cats die and you didn’t tell me? Are these replacement cats?  65.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No! They are the same goddamn cats! Brooke stares at the cats hard and then stomps outside. Tracy wants to go after her but follows Mamie-Claire into living room. Tony and Nicolette play chess. The pregnant woman still s by the door checking her phone periodically. Tony thinks hard before a move. He moves his rook--

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: If you do that, your knight is vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What? Oh...thanks.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: You took your finger off it, you made the move. Mamie-Claire enters. Tracy behind her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: “I took my finger off it?” Who am I playing here Deep Blue? He looks at Karen for a laugh. Doesn’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Karen, come inside, have a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I’m fine. He’1l be here.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (indignant to Mamie- Claire) So you deny it? That you profited from her idea that you stole?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No, I don’t deny it. She’s right. The T-shirts were her idea.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Then why did you just say that?!

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I like making her mad. It’s so easy.  66.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You took her idea. That’s not just, Mamie-Claire.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No, I tried to include her. I set up a meeting with people and she never showed up. And then she stopped speaking to me when me and Dylan got married so I figured I could just go do it.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: So it’s her fault.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No... She is right that I stole a lot of her life ideas. I really am not as creative as she is. But she never would have used them. She has no follow through.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: So it’s... no one’s fault.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Obviously. That’s always true.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You know the restaurant is going to be really great. She’s following through with that. If she’s allowed to. Tracy leaves to go find Brooke. At the chess table:

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Wait, what? No it isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Check. Tony stands, pretends he’s being rational.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to play anymore.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Oh come on!  67.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t feel like playing right now.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: You can’t quit right before I’m going to win--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m just not in the mood. People can be not in the mood. Mamie-Claire stares at them.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I couldn’t be your mother, thank god.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What are you, thirty? We’re eighteen. You could. Twelve year olds can have kids.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Mamie-Claire!

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Karen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BACKYARD. DAY
dialogues.text: Brooke, still worked up, marches across the lawn. Her pho vibrates.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hey Dad - what’s up? I can’t really talk right now.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Brooke...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I‘1l1 call you tomorrow, I’m in the middle of something.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I know you probably don’t care --

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: -- I care about things!  Tears run 68.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: But I’m not getting married.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: No... We called it off last night. It’s for the best. I don’t really know her.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: She wasn’t committed to the church, either. I think that was all forced.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Sure, sure.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yes, I just... You’re really not doing it? I thought you guys were really symbiotic. Wasn’t it a web algorithm that got you together? She seems amazing.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: You never even met Stevie.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Through you, I met her. I don’t know, Dad. Come on... down Brooke's face.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Don’t just bail. That’s what the Cardinases always do, move on to something else. Hang in there.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Frankly I’m surprised you’re so invested in this. Believe me, it’s for the best.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (wiping her face) I have to go. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a really important business meeting. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: We can do Thanksgiving at my house if you want - since there won’t be a wedding.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Nah, I'll probably just end up doing something depressing but young.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Home is only a bus ride away.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Is it? Just kidding, it is. There is a silence between them for a second.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: So what does this make me and Tracy?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Who’s Tracy?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, right, her daughter - nothing, I guess. INT. MAMIE-CLAIRE’S DEN. DAY Tracy is looking through an old datebook in the den. She picks up a 1970's subway token and puts in her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (startles) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sorry, I didn’t mean to sneak.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (saucily) Are you stalking me?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I left my backpack in here. I need my migrane pills.  70. He goes to his backpack and gets out an pill bottle. He fixes himself a scotch and then downs a pill.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Let me have a sip. She takes the glass from him. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: How much longer do you think we’1l be here?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, however long it takes. After Dylan comes home maybe.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What are you really trying to accomplish here?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (looking around the room) I’m enjoying this really stylish house. When you live in suburbia you have to really like being in your house.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That’s not what I - what are you doing with this whole thing? Nicolette appears in the doorway for a second and then retreats, listening.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I want Brooke to get her restaurant. I’m helping out. Tony goes to his backpack, which was thrown on the couch. Opens it and retrieves the pages she had given him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I read your story, by the way. (he holds up the pages) Brooke is the woman in your piece. You're collecting material.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Did you like it?  71.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (evasive) That’s not what we’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (vaguely) You needed a ride. You forced me. Tracy quickly walks over to Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: How does it feel to be forced?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It feels...uncomfortable. Tracy puts her face close to his. She removes his glasses

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: And how do you feel now?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Still uncomfortable. Tracy kisses Tony passionately on the mouth. Nicolette reacts.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (pushing her off) That’s not what I want!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It is what you want, but it makes you feel like a bad person to want it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (wiping his mouth) You're acting really crazy. I don’t like this. He puts the story back into his backpack.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Why can’t you say you liked my story?  72.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (upset) I don’t know! I’m jealous! It’s better than mine! Sheesh!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You want other people to do the things that you can’t so you can blame them.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You used to be so nice.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m the same. I’m just the same in another direction now. Tony and Tracy leave. Nicolette enters, goes to Tony’s backpack and takes out the story.

dialogues.speaker: YOU'RE HOME
dialogues.text: INT. MAMIE-CLAIRE’S HOUSE. DAY Dylan, a round annoyed-looking blonde man, is fixing a dr and doing dishes and Mamie Claire is trying to really hug with her face in his neck.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I don’t like it when you try to force affection onto me.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I’m just trying to hug you.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Do you have to put your face so close to mine?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It’s nice....

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You know how upset I get when I visit the home...

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I want you to share it with me.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Rosella and Lorene may not even be ALIVE next time I’m there, okay? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just keep your face a little away while I process that.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (pouting) Fine. Dylan looks up -- he clocks Tony, Tracy and Karen, the abandoned Pregnant Woman, at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Who are all these people?! MC, why do you never tell me who is in the house?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I wondered if I could have some water.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Of course, Karen. She goes to retrieve a glass.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Oh, hi Karen, I don’t mean you.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (reaching out his hand) Tony, nice to meet you. Beautiful house sir.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (confused) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Have you seen a girl about this high - (demonstrates with his hand) - that’s my girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: No, uh, there’s more of you? Tracy steps in a little:

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (pointing at himself) Dylan. Tracy is a tight name. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a name that totally is a name but I don’t know anyone actually named Tracy, you know?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I am actually named Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tracy--

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (turning) Yeah? Brooke enters. Dylan sees Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Brooke. Brooke now notices Dylan.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hey Dylan. They stand apart almost shyly.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Brooke’s here with some kindergartners.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) What were you going to say?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (smiling at Dylan) In a minute.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Has anyone seen Nicolette?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Forget about Nicolette for a second.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Stop trying to seduce me! Mamie-Claire hands Karen her water.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Thanks, I got a little parched. I think I’m sitting by a heating duct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoves a stool in her direction) Stay here. Have a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: No. Ted really should be here soon.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Karen! 75. Karen sits on the stool. Tony looks distraught.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can I have a snack? Stress makes me hungry. Mamie-Claire gestures to the refrigerator. Tony opens the freezer and fridge stands in front of it. Dylan considers Brooke. Mamie-Claire watches.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Brooke -- I haven't seen you in a second.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I know, right?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: What brings you to the burbs?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: We were--

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Brooke needs money.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No, I don’t “need money” - I come to you with an opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I told her about the taxi medallions.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Let me make you a drink. What’s the opportunity?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (coyly) It’s a good one.  76.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: We're having dinner at the Baskins. I’m sorry to say it but you guys will have to leave now. Tony holds up a Chipwich.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can I have this?

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: He leaves, eating the Chipwich.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Marty and Jiselle can wait.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Didn’t you guys park over at Harold's?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (confused) You guys know Harold? How do you know Harold?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: They don’t!

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: She's an old friend, she can stay over if she wants. We have the room for her and her students.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: They’re not her students. It’s much weirder than that. (definitively) I’11 walk you out. Mamie-Claire leaves through the door toward the living ro No one follows.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: They’re my friends.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Always running with a young crowd.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: She’s starting a restaurant.  77.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I can’t wait to tell you about it. Mamie-Claire reenters, realizing no one followed.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Dylan, let’s not do this. She already lost her shit once.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: What’s the restaurant? Dylan starts doing the dishes/loading the dishwasher.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Brooke, this is uncomfortable. Dylan doesn’t want to do this.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (to Mamie-Claire) You don’t know what I want. I know you see me a certain way, but I’m not just some square. I saw Nirvana live and this was way before Nevermind.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (piping in) You seem really cool to me.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I DJed at my college radio station, the 2AM slot. We played Mudhoney, Superchunk, Trip Shakespeare, I mean...

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No one wants to hear about your glory days in college radio, Dylan, OK.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY /BROOKE
dialogues.text: I do./I do.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (back to Mamie-Claire) I play this part for you. I play this guy wearing a fleece, but I’m not just some asshole bankrolling your fitness goals.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I’ve gotten really into triathalons.  78.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Brooke teaches cycling.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: So cool.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No, I only like cycling when it’s combined with running and swimming.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) Why did you think of us?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Because we “owe” her!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Because you’re into cool things.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We are! You guys want to smoke some weed? He opens the freezer.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I have some frozen weed. MC, where’s that weed Jason gave us?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: You've just said “weed” like fifteen times.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (head in the freezer) MC??? Did that kid take my weed!?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: NO! No one has touched it. It should be next to the Chipwiches. CUT TO: Tony knocks on the upstairs bathroom door. He’s eating a Chipwich.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Are you sick?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, I’m healthy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Don’t shut me out! You know how hard that is for me!  79.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You sound like you’re eating something.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I have a Chipwich for you.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (softening) You brought me a Chipwich?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I can get you another one.

dialogues.speaker: LEAVE ME ALONE
dialogues.text: Nicolette reads the story on the sink counter.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was clear that the thing that Meadow wanted most in the world - the thing that she wanted to define her, to absolve her from the struggle of explaining herself, to give her a place to put her time and talents - her everything - the restaurant. Tony pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was clear that it would never happen. The most surprising thing was that Meadow was actually surprised by it. She could see the whole world with painful accuracy but couldn’t see herself or her fate.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Baby, come out!

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Brooke finds herself standing next to Karen.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The most surprising thing was that Meadow was actually surprised by it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And because I was in love with her, I decided I couldn’t see it either. The conversations overlap.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I'm starting a restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Oh...I’m an attorney.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: That’s awesome for you. I never went to college.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: That doesn’t have to be a permanent state. You aren’t an amputee.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You can still go to college.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (head still in the freezer) We'll get lifted and you'll tell us about this venture. Dylan reemerges holding a Chipwich.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Do any of you kids know how to make an apple bong?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (nearly apoplectic) Nobody knows how to make an apple bong! Tony comes back:

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Did you take my herb?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I’1l get you an apple.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Why don’t we all sit down somewhere comfortable and listen to what Brooke has to say...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Yes. You'll pitch us.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: That’s what you do. If someone wants something. They pitch. Come pitch us on our media stage! Dylan, Tracy, Tony and Brooke all troupe down the hall. Mamie-Claire hurries behind:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We just ran Apocalypto on Blu Ray. Stunning. Stunning. I’ve gotten very into vinyl.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m into compressed MP3’s. Just joking.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I have a great early Mother Love Bone EP that would be perfect for this occasion.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Records are so warm. Brooke is suddenly yanked out of the line of people, by M Claire who stands in the dark in the guest bathroom:

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (intense whisper) I want you to know that I really love Dylan. I love his blonde hair and his beard. I know you only loved him for his money but I love him as a person and I also love him for his money but not in that order. I’m committed to being a happier person. Do you understand? She releases Brooke back out into the hallway.  82.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Dylan, Mamie-Claire, Tony, Karen and Tracy sit on the cou in front of an elevated stage which is usually used to project movies. Brooke stands behind a curtain. Tracy presses a button an the curtain slowly opens. Brooke appears before them. Brooke backs up and kind of g a little presentational about the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Umm, well...it’s a restaurant, but also like where you cut hair... (hesitates) Can I start over?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Of course. We’re old friends. Murmurs of “yes, of course.”

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Okay, great. She does a weird “rewinding” type action. Everyone stares

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I was, that was pretend rewind. Like... Then she does it again.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (breath) So...it would have big heavy wooden tables and chairs and... Suddenly a projection of the red FBI warning from a DVD appears across Brooke’s body. She hesitates. Dylan pulls the remote control from under his body.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Sorry. He shuts off the image.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Umm... It would feel like the home everyone wishes they had been raised in. It...it...it...it.  83. Brooke is struggling. Tracy can’t help but pipe in from t couch.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No one who comes there will want to take out their cell phones because it won't feel that way. It would be like taking out your cell phone in the woods - totally wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: It’s so rude. I concur.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah. It will always feel like fall inside - even on hot summer nights with all the windows open.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Loaves of bread that people tear off pieces. It would be the kind of place where at 2AM the chef and the wait-staff would come out and eat something simple they fixed themselves with the remaining guests and open a bottle of good wine.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (standing up) It would be the best of capitalism. What politicians pretend they mean when they say “small business.”

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: We would resist doing too many pieces in the Times and stuff because we'd want it to stay honest. They would want us to expand and open another one and Maybe we eventually would but we wouldn't try to re-create the first one, it would be a totally new thing. And if I ever had kids they would walk there after school and do their homework in a corner table. They’d grow up around all these wonderful adults -

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Chefs and actors who are waiters - it would be a big funny family and they’d never be lonely.  Silence. 84.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: This could all be something you guys share in - you'd be their auntie and uncle - part of the life and food. And eventually I'd train someone younger than myself to run the day to day so I could go up to Maine with my family in the summers and have the kids dive for lobsters and everyone would be so warm and happy inside knowing that in their life they had participated in something that was only good. Tracy is kind of emotional. Everyone applauds. Karen is sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Wow. Dylan walks up to Brooke, kissing her on each cheek, pretending to be speechless.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (to the group) You know, I lived in the City for Many years. Before I started at Goldman, I was teaching at Baruch and I lived in an East Village walk- up. I was the people people make television shows about. (to Tracy) I was quite beautiful. He takes Brooke’s hand. Mamie-Claire reacts. Takes his other hand. They are all holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: This is very fucking interesting.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (re: Tracy and Brooke) So, are you both doing it?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No, but we’re sisters and I’m--

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Tracy is spiritual guidance and waitress.  85.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (thrilled) Really? I wasn’t sure you had heard me those times.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I hear everything.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: How much do you need?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It’s 200 total but I calculated we need forty-two point five on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: For refrigeration.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Forty-two point five stacks, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What are stacks?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: A thousand?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I thought “stacks” meant a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I’m pretty sure a stack is a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I think a dime is a thousand. (cutting to the chase) Nevermind, you'd do that?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I want to help you. The door bell rings. Karen springs off her stool.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: That’s Ted! Bye everyone.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) Good luck with your restaurant!  86. She hurries out. He starts

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Dylan, this is really something for us to talk about privately.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We need fresh drinks. for the kitchen. Brooke follows.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Umm, Mamie-Claire! Can you come here please?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Can it wait, Karen?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No! Mamie-Claire hesitates, torn between keeping and eye of D and going to Karen, and then runs to Karen. CUT TO: Harold is at the door. Karen stands there, confus

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: It’s not Ted.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Harold--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I am calling the cops. You were warned.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Could the weed be in the garage freezer?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t know!

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can you check?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (yelling) I’m blowing Harold so he doesn’t call the cops. JK. I’m probably just going to have to go look at his boat collection.  87.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (stepping inside) I can’t remember the last time I was over here.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t think you’ve ever been over here, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No, when you first moved here, I came for a stilted barbecue.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That’s when we made an effort.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, invite me in now. I want a house tour.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Tony is working on the apple bong with his all-purpose to Tracy watches him.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You are such a Swiss Army knife kind of guy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I have to be a better loser. I really love Nicolette.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: She’s angry about the chess game?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think so. I’m mostly in touch with my feminine side but then I guess not though because I don’t understand her right now.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Did you... did you want to be with me ever?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to get into this...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No, I’m not going to kiss you. Just a question. Tony considers:  88.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I liked you, but I love Nicolette and honestly... I just never saw you that way.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You seemed... I need someone I can love, not keep up with.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (nodding) Sometimes I really think I’m just smarter and better than everyone else. Not necessarily with math or science or whether something is east or west but pretty much with everything else. And if I could just figure out my look I'd be the most beautiful woman in the world too.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think I’m a genius and I wish I could just fast-forward my life to the part where everyone knows it. Tony holds up the completed apple bong. It’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Brooke has followed Dylan into the kitchen, he’s fixing a drink.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I have to say, I’m impressed Brooke. It takes a lot of moxie to start a restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You're doing it, babe. You’re out there, doing something besides amassing and hoarding money.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: If I could figure out how to amass and hoard money, I'd do it.  89.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You could have married me or a dozen other guys but you wanted to be your own person.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, no, I’m over that now. Dylan laughs. He moves toward her. She moves in.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You’re funny because you don’t know you’re funny.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I know I’m funny. There’s nothing I don’t know about myself. That’s why I can’t do therapy. They’re close now. He pushes a strand out of her face and behind her ear. Brooke is going with it.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: MC and I see a woman in New Haven.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh...you guys see a therapist? Like a tune up?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: More like a death watch. She’s totally on my side. She basically thinks Mamie-Claire is holding me back and I should just leave her.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Your couple’s therapist said that?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: In so many words. Yeah, we're done.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (sadly) Mamie-Claire said you were trying to have kids.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We've talked about it but we’ve also talked about breaking up.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh no, I’m sorry--  90.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: No, it’s liberating. I feel great.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (freaked out) Yay...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I miss New York, man. I miss you. I look you up periodically on the internet. You look hot as hell in those party pictures. Brooke takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh...do I? Which party? Sometimes I look like I have fat arms. He takes another step forward.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I like fat arms. I’m going to help you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (tearful) Thank you. She hugs him. He holds the hug too long. She has to yank herself free.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Here's what I’m going to do for you. We’ll take my forty-three stacks or dimes and pay back the other investors, whatever they’re in for thus far. You got a space already? A lease? Brooke, realizing, nods.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We'll put it up for rent immediately, cool neighborhood?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (almost inaudible) Williamsburg.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Oh, come on! The coolest. Yeah, we'll turn it over no problem. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gl.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because let’s face it having a restaurant is like having a kid with a drug problem. It’s...just...it’s really draining.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (crushed) You're giving me money to not start a restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: First of all - I’m saving you. If you started the restaurant, you’d be back here in a year asking for five times this.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Not if it was successful --

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: What are the odds? He pushes a hair away from her face. He’s close to her no

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You’re as beautiful as ever. Whatever you're doing it’s working.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No. No, it isn’t. Brooke hesitates. Dylan grins. Tracy enters.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Did you ever find the pot? Tony just made a beautiful apple bong.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We'll have to, because some celebrating is in order. (putting his arm around Brooke ) I think we may have reached a deal.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (shaking off her disappointment ) Yes... Dylan made a proposition.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I’m going to give her money immediately.  92.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yay!

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're giving her money? Mamie-Claire enters. Dylan takes his arm off of Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Who was at the door?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Harold. He’s giving himself a tour of the house.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Where’s Karen?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t fucking know. You're giving her money??? This is our decision. Not yours.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I’m not giving her 200 grand, don’t worry, I'm just bailing her out of her current situation. Tracy looks at Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: And then for the whole restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (trying to be brave) No... I won’t do the restaurant now. It’s just gotten too crazy.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (to Tracy) You believe in her, don’t you? Tracy nods. Brooke watches her.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: This is a good result, this is even better than getting the restaurant. Less financial uncertainty.  93.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: He’s right. I think I even feel a little relieved.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: “Mom's” wasn’t about money.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t think anyone starts anything with the dream of NOT making money.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Do they not?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Why would you give her money?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: It’s my money. I make it. I can do what I want with it. Just like, you have your T-shirt money, you can do what you want with that.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: But I... we’re married. This is our life. Brooke looks at Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You know what, I appreciate it, Dylan, Mamie-Claire, but I’m not going to take the money. I/’11 figure something else out.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Why? Brooke looks at Mamie-Claire.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I just wasn’t brought up that way. Mamie-Claire smiles at her. An unspoken “Thanks.” Tracy comes over to Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What will you do?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I'll figure it out. I always do.  94.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m so impressed by you and worried for you at the same time. She hugs Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m so glad you're my sister. Brooke is about to say something when they HEAR SHOUTING. INT. MAMIE-CLAIRE’S LIVING ROOM. IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING Dylan, Mamie-Claire, Brooke and Tracy enter. Nicolette an Tony are arguing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I love YOU!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Don’t lie to my face and stab me in the back butter boy!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey, that’s mean... She sees Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: You're stealing my boyfriend! You're cuckholding me! She starts hitting Tracy. Harold and Karen enter.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: You bitch whore!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Guys!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) She just started attacking her!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (walking in) What IS it about this house? Everyone screams.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Please stop it! Brooke helps Mamie-Claire pull Nicolette off Tracy.  95.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (still struggling) She's stealing my boyfriend!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I am not!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I resisted! I resisted!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Chill the fuck out.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Ladies, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (re: her stomach) I don’t like shouting around the baby.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (to Karen) Is that a real thing?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'm right here, she’s not stealing anything...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s NOT just that! There’s also

dialogues.speaker: THIS
dialogues.text: The pulls a wrinkled stack of papers out of her pants.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: What the fuck is that?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Or cursing.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: Tracy knows what it is. I'’1l give you a hint: it’s onion skin. CLOSE on Tracy. Nicolette points at her.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (pointing her finger) She's a HOMEWRECKER and a bad person.  96.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) It’s not you... It’s just inspired. You make me want to write.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: This is so nerdy.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Who wouldn’t want to write a story about Brooke?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (vaising her hand) Me. I wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Nicolette) Baby, I resisted.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (settling in, taking a seat) Can I get a drink?

dialogues.speaker: PREGNANT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Here, have mine. (giving him her wine) They keep handing me alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (to Tracy) You wrote a story about me?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) She hates you - she wrote mean things about you.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No I didn’t!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I'd like to read it. If it’s about me.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I'd like to, too.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (to Dylan) You don’t read fiction.  97.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: When it’s about my friends I do.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) Oh, it’s not really you, but it’s very funny, the character that Nicolette and Tony misconstrued as you is a very funny character.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (not thrilled with this) Funny? What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’s not funny. It’s just...it’s not you.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) Do you live in an apartment that’s zoned commercial? Brooke hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Gimme that story. She snatches it out of Nicolette’s hands. CUT TO: Brooke reads with Mamie-Claire, Karen, Harold and Dylan all reading over her shoulder. Tony and Nicolette a hover in the background, reading here and there. Tracy watches nervously from across the room. Brooke starts to turn the page. Everyone indicates they’r not finished with that page yet. CUT TO: Brooke turns the final page. She looks at Tracy. She is FURIOUS.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t meant to be hurtful - I didn’t mean to hurt you, Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (shaking with fury) You don’t get to decide what’s hurtful and not hurtful.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I can only tell you my intention.  98.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You wrote this after ONE night with me? ONE?!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I guess so, yeah, it felt longer.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You think I’m a rotting carcass? That I’m doomed to failure???

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No! It’s fiction that’s why it’s fiction...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: So much of this “fiction” did NOT happen this way. Karen, you’re a lawyer. I’m going to sue you until you have NOTHING.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I'm just writing from my life...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No, this isn’t your life!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: But I was there that night.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: NO! I was going to have that night anyway, you never were!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: But I did have it though.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You joined my life - you needed a place to go and I invited you in and then you stole my life. You’re a LEECH. A BLOODSUCKER.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You loved being admired by me, you loved it, you loved having lessons to impart...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I DIDN’T ASK FOR YOU. Tracy looks for support from Tony and Nicolette.  99.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Brooke, you know great plays, right? - how would it have been if Tennessee Williams hadn’t used people he knew, there wouldn’t be any plays, there wouldn’t -

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I DON’T GIVE A SHIT BECAUSE I AM NOT A FRIEND OF TENNESSEE WILLIAMS.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You took something I said and made a tweet about it! What about that?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: That's different! You were right there! You knew I was Twittering, it wasn’t some sneaky shitty thing - do you want me to credit you? Or no I‘ll just delete it.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: That’s not the point I’m asking you to empathize.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It’s my least popular tweet anyway!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Stop talking about Twitter, it’s so awkward!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You are much more of an asshole than you initially appear.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (looking again at the story) And...you think I haven't dealt with the pain of my mother’s death? I deal with it all the time, I talk about it all the time.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You talk about it all the time, but you never talk about HER. You just throw out that she died and that shuts everyone up. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your tragedy is your armor in which nothing is ever your fault. Brooke looks around, desperately wild eyed, looking for support.

dialogues.speaker: DEFEND ME AGAINST THIS MONSTER
dialogues.text: Everyone jumps on Tracy, agreeing with Brooke, says she’s dick.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: It’s like your whole generation, it’s all pastiche. Mamie-Claire has been writing. She finishes and calmly jo the discussion.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: The emotional betrayal I can’t speak to -

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I didn’t “betray” her -

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: But I can say that you portray women terribly. And because of that. Mamie-Claire refers to her piece of neatly folded paper.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I’ve prepared some questions I'd like you to think about.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: And I want you to answer these questions, not for our satisfaction, but for your own. (gazing at her paper) One: Do you believe in the women’s right to choose?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yes, what does that -

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I’m not done.  101.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: She’s not done, bitch!

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Brooke, please. Two: What do you think someone who bombs abortion clinics would think of your story?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: There isn’t even an abortion in this story!

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: No you just portray women as crazy desperate gold diggers!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) You seemed so cool so totally amazing I didn’t think it would be possible to hurt you...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Of COURSE it’s possible, I am the MOST sensitive person...

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: To your own feelings.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (wailing) Mamie-Claire!

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Sorry, I don’t really think that, it’s just something I would have said at one time.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I have to say, what you did to Brooke is f-ed up.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Karen, you don’t see my side?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: No, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You don’t have a side you’re just wrong.  102.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: You must call the Lit Society and tell them you’re withdrawing your essay--

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’s not an essay, it’s a short story.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: This cannot appear in print or online. Karen, will you represent Brooke?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I’m a tax attorney, but OK.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Will you draw up a contract, please?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Yes, and in the meantime, I’m going to ask you to rewrite the story and give Brooke the rewritten story. I‘1l give you my email and you can BCC me.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogues.text: She could just CC you.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nic’s right, because we'd already know that you’re getting it...

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Sure, CC me.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) Technology can be complicated.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I know! I just learned what “case sensitive” meant seriously yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m not going to do any of this stuff. You’re my sister and I love you but I stand by what I did.  103.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Guess what, bitch? My dad isn’t going to marry your slutty atheist mother so we’re not sisters. We never will be. We’re nothing to each other. Mamie-Claire tucks her folded paper into Tracy’s pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: There are ten questions there. All equally important for you to answer.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Brooke... But Brooke won’t look at her. EXT. MAMIE-CLAIRE’S HOUSE. EVE Tracy sits alone. She smokes from the apple bong.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. MORNING
dialogues.text: Tracy rides on the train. She opens Mamie-Claire’s questions. She reads them to herself.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DORM HALLWAY. EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Tracy opens the door to her room. Her mom is sitting on t bed. She looks like she’s been crying.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Oh, honey! Ruth signed me in. CUT TO: Tracy’s Mom is crying. Tracy sits next to her on bed.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: The Catholicism thing has been kind of crazy and he kind of -- I just saw a side of him that I didn’t know before. It’s strange to not really know someone...

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I know you liked Brooke. He told me that she worships you, she kept talking about how smart you are, how interesting... Tracy starts crying. She cries

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Oh, honey, don’t cry, you can still be friends...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I went -- I went through a breakup too.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: You didn’t tell me you were dating anyone.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I know. harder.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Oh my sweet girl. Do you want to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No, it’s too late now anyway. Mom rubs Tracy’s back.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I know this is crappy timing, but I need to take a vacation, and I got the deposit back for the flowers and Colleen told me to come with her family to the Caribbean over Thanksgiving, and Trace, I need it.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that sounds nice, Stevie.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: So you're okay, for Thanksgiving, not coming home? I’m sure your father would love to have you...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh, I didn’t put that together - yes, I’m fine. I'll be fine. Are you okay?  105.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I’m sad. I’m very sad. But I’1l be okay.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I wish it had worked, even though I didn’t really know him.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Me too, Baby Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DORM ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tracy's sleeping. She looks peaceful. We HEAR a door open footsteps and suddenly a pie is jammed in her face. Tracy screams. And screams. And screams. The members of the Mobius Lit Club all stop in their trac The boy in the sweater vest says:

dialogues.speaker: SWEATER VEST
dialogues.text: You're in.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAMPUS QUAD. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy walks with the Sweater Vest Boy. She holds a briefcase. She sees Tony and Nicolette across the path. They see her and then look away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBRARY. DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE on The Mobius Literary Journal. Tracy opens it up t her story: Mistress America by Tracy Fishko. She reads it again in the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAMPUS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tree lighting ceremony. Tracy walks under the lit trees.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PSYCHIC WAITING AREA. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy waits. INT. PSYCHIC’S APARTMENT. DAY Tracy sits across from the Psychic.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Sometimes I worry that I’m a bad person. That I’m one of those people who essentially has no conscience.  106.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: Spirit says that you need to find your home in yourself. The Psychic suddenly takes her hand:

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: Spirit says that you haven't dropped into your body yet.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: If I’m not in my body, where am I?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIC
dialogues.text: Five feet to the left and unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HUDSON RIVER. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy hurls her briefcase into the water.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy sits in front of the Advisor.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: If a person wanted to start their own club, how would a person go about it?

dialogues.speaker: ADVISOR
dialogues.text: Well, I think it’s pretty much done for this semester, but you could put in an application for funding for next semester... INT. TONY’S DORM ROOM. DAY A knock on the door. Tony answers it.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Hey, can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Tracy sits on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You going home for Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, going to Baltimore with Nicolette.  107.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh...nice.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Her dad fries a turkey apparently. You?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Nah. She hands Tony a couple of pieces of paper.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’s an application. Two.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to join Mobius. I've had enough rejection.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’s not for Mobius. I quit the briefcase club. You were right, they're self-appointed douche bags. I’m starting my own zine and I’m not saying you’re in, but I am saying I'd be very interested in getting your and Nicolette’s application. Tony stands, he thinks about this for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'll fix us some screwdrivers.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Tracy goes by the restaurant. For Let. Tracy goes to Soul Cycle, a different instructor. Thanksgiving Day parade. Tracy watches the floats alone. INT. BROOKE’S APARTMENT BUILDING. HALLWAY. AFTERNOON Tracy knocks on a door. Kareem, in a tie, answers.

dialogues.speaker: KAREEM
dialogues.text: Hello.  108.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Hi - I’m sorry to bother you on Thanksgiving, but I met you once - I went through your window? It was in the middle of the night...

dialogues.speaker: KAREEM
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I was with Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: KAREEM
dialogues.text: You're her sister, right?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Well, I was going to be. Do you have a number for her? The old one isn’t working...

dialogues.speaker: KAREEM
dialogues.text: I don’t--

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Anyway - I was going to ask you: do you know where she went? Kareem indicates for Tracy to follow him. She passes thro a cozy apartment. The table is set for the holiday. A couple of kids run through.

dialogues.speaker: KAREEM
dialogues.text: Her front door is still bolted shut. They reach the window. Kareem opens it.

dialogues.speaker: KAREEM
dialogues.text: She's upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIRE ESCAPE. DAY
dialogues.text: Tracy climbs the fire escape. She gets to the top window looks through the glass. The place is mostly empty save for stacked boxes and suitcases. Brooke walks into the room and places some books into a b She wears her red pants. Tracy knocks. Brooke looks up an comes to the window. She and Tracy stare at each other through the glass.  109.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (through the glass) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Can I come in? CUT TO: Tracy sits on some boxes watching Brooke move aro packing.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You're leaving?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: In a couple of hours. I’m going to try my luck out west.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You're going today? On Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: New York isn’t the New York I used to know. There’s too much construction. Maybe LA is my lady. In LA I qualify as well-read.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I wanted to say--

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I know you’re sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I’m not really that sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You're not?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh then fuck this. Brooke opens the window again.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No, no wait... (pause) I looked for you.  110.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I’ve been around.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Are you OK? Like, financially?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Mamie-Claire gave me what would have been my share of our T- shirt profits. It was just enough to pay off my debts and get out of town.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What will you do in LA?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think I’m sick. And I don’t know if my ailment has a name - it’s just me sitting and staring at the internet or the television for long periods of time interspersed by trying to not do that and then lying about what I’ve been doing. Then I’1l get so excited about something that the excitement overwhelms me and I can’t sleep or do anything - and then I just am in love with everything but can’t figure out how to make myself work in the world.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I think I have that too.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I wish we lived in feudal times when your position in the world couldn’t change. If you were a king or a peasant you had to just be happy with who you were. (pause) But...wait! Brooke looks inside an open box. She finds a piece of pap and hands it to Tracy. CLOSE: SAT results. 2200.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You can tutor SAT’s now.  111.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Well, I thought I might actually go to college. I’m not an amputee.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (confused) Right.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I filled out a couple of applications. I wrote my college essay all about you.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (apprehensive) Really?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh snap! No. It’s about my mom. But I had you there.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Brooke goes into the other room to retrieve more books.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I let Mamie-Claire and Dylan keep the cats. It’s like, I gave thema chance for a better life, better than I could have provided for them.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: The cats went from stolen to given because you changed your mind.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t put that in a story. Not because I care but because it’s not a very good observation. Tracy sees the Mobius Literary Journal (the one with her story) inside an open box. She’s about to say something, thinks better of it. Brooke reenters and tosses books int the box.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You know what’s funny... I’m not even done with my first semester of college.  112.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: This won’t even be your big “college story.”

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I think it’1ll always be pretty big. Brooke hesitates, emotional for a second. She musses Trac hair like a kid.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for stopping by, but I have more packing to do before Kareem and I break down the front door.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’ll be hard for me not to look at New York and think of you somewhere in it. Brooke shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Tracy moves toward the window. She looks back at her frie

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Hey Brooke... Brooke turns around.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It’s not going to be as great as what my mom and your dad were planning, but... Do you want to have Thanksgiving with me?

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. VESELKA. DAY
dialogues.text: We watch Brooke and Tracy through the window eating piero for Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Meadow had made rich fat women less fat and rich stupid kids less stupid and lame rich men less lame. And she wanted so badly to be on the other side - to be fat and stupid and lame and rich. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But what she couldn't see most of all, more than she couldn't see that she was never going to get the restaurant, was that those people were nothing compared to her. They were matches to her bonfire. She was the last cowboy - all romance and failure. The world was changing and her kind didn’t have anywhere to go. Being a beacon of hope for lesser people is a lonely business. And as Brooke and Tracy talk and reminisce and laugh, we TO BLACK.
